'''John<!--This is correct, please do not change. "Jack" is a common hypocorism for "John"--> Luman Smith''' (born June 5, 1969) is an American attorney who has served in the [[United States Department of Justice]] as an [[assistant U.S. attorney]], acting [[U.S. attorney]], and head of the department's [[Public Integrity Section]]. He was also the chief prosecutor at the [[Kosovo Specialist Chambers]], an international tribunal at [[The Hague]] tasked with investigating and prosecuting [[war crimes in the Kosovo War]].

In November 2022, attorney general [[Merrick Garland]] appointed Smith an independent [[special counsel]], responsible for overseeing two preexisting Justice Department criminal investigations into former president [[Donald Trump]], three days after Trump announced his [[Donald Trump 2024 presidential campaign|2024 presidential campaign]]: one regarding Trump's role in the [[January 6 U.S. Capitol attack]], and the other into [[FBI investigation into Donald Trump's handling of government documents|alleged mishandling of government records, including classified documents]]. The documents case resulted in a [[Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (government documents case)|37-count indictment]] of Trump in June 2023 to which three counts were later added in July.<ref>{{Cite web |first1=Tierney |last1=Sneed |first2=Marshall |last2=Cohen |first3=Jeremy |last3=Herb |date=2023-07-27 |title=Special counsel brings more charges against Donald Trump in Mar-a-Lago classified documents case |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/07/27/politics/trump-mar-a-lago-special-counsel/ |access-date=2023-07-28 |website=CNN |language=en}}</ref> In August, the January 6 case resulted in an [[Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (2020 election case)|indictment]] on four charges.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last=Gannon |first=Tierney Sneed, Marshall Cohen, Zachary Cohen, Devan Cole, Hannah Rabinowitz, Katelyn Polantz, Casey |date=2023-08-01 |title=Donald Trump has been indicted in special counsel's 2020 election interference probe {{!}} CNN Politics |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/08/01/politics/donald-trump-indictment-grand-jury-2020-election/index.html |access-date=2023-08-02 |website=CNN |language=en}}</ref>

==Early life and education==
Smith was born on June 5, 1969.<ref name=NYTimes2023-06-08>{{Cite news |last=Thrush |first=Glenn |date=June 8, 2023 |access-date =June 11, 2023 |title=Who Is Jack Smith, the Special Counsel Who Indicted Trump? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/06/08/us/politics/jack-smith-special-counsel-trump-indictment.html |newspaper=The New York Times |url-access=limited}}</ref> He grew up in [[Clay, New York]], a suburb of [[Syracuse, New York|Syracuse]].<ref name=yost>{{cite news |access-date=November 19, 2022 |date=August 30, 2010 |url=https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sdut-dojs-elite-public-integrity-unit-gets-new-leader-2010aug30-story.html |title=DOJ's elite Public Integrity unit gets new leader |newspaper=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |first=Pete |last=Yost }}</ref><ref name=savage>{{Cite news |last1=Savage |first1=Charlie |last2=Feuer |first2=Alan |date=November 19, 2022 |title=In New Special Counsel, a Prosecutor Schooled in Corruption Cases |work=[[The New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/19/us/politics/jack-smith-trump-special-counsel.html |access-date=November 21, 2022 |url-access=limited}}</ref> His father was a draftsman of air-conditioning systems; his mother was a homemaker for most of Smith's childhood.<ref name="Roig">{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/style/power/2023/10/03/jack-smith-profile-prosecutor-trump/|title=What's it like to be prosecuted by Jack Smith?|last=Roig-Franzia|first=Manuel|date=October 3, 2023|newspaper=The Washington Post|access-date=4 October 2023}}</ref> He graduated from [[Liverpool High School]] in 1987,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://eaglenewsonline.com/new/government/2022/11/18/liverpool-named-special-counsel-for-trump-investigation/ |access-date=November 19, 2022 |date=November 18, 2022 |title=Liverpool grad named special counsel to oversee Trump investigations |newspaper=[[Eagle Newspapers (New York)|Eagle News Online]] |first=Ashley M. |last=Casey }}</ref> where he played [[American football|football]] and [[baseball]].<ref name="Liverpool football">{{cite news |last1=Eisenstadt |first1=Marnie |title=How Jack Smith went from Liverpool football bench to a starring role in Trump investigation |url=https://www.syracuse.com/news/2022/12/how-jack-smith-went-from-liverpool-football-bench-to-a-starring-role-in-trumps-prosecution.html |access-date=December 14, 2022 |work=[[syracuse.com]] |date=December 14, 2022 |language=en}}</ref> He then studied [[political science]] at the [[State University of New York at Oneonta]], graduating in 1991 with a [[Bachelor of Arts]], ''[[Latin honors#United States|summa cum laude]]''.<ref name="Liverpool football"/><ref>{{cite web |access-date=November 19, 2022 |url=https://lawandcrime.com/trump/special-counsel-tapped-by-merrick-garland-to-investigate-trump-formerly-prosecuted-top-democrats-and-republicans/ |website=[[Law & Crime]] |title=Special Counsel Tapped by Merrick Garland to Investigate Trump Formerly Prosecuted Top Democrats and Republicans |date=November 18, 2022 |first=Aaron |last=Keller }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Scott |first=Eugene |date=November 18, 2022 |title= Who is Jack Smith, special counsel in Trump criminal investigation? |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2022/11/18/trump-justice-department-mar-a-lago/ |access-date=November 18, 2022}}</ref> Smith then attended [[Harvard Law School]], from which he graduated ''cum laude'' in 1994 with the degree of [[Juris Doctor]].<ref name=savage/>

== Career ==
[[File:Jack_Smith.jpg|left|thumb|Smith in 2017 while acting U.S. attorney for the Middle District of Tennessee]]
After graduating from law school, Smith joined the [[Manhattan District Attorney]]'s office, serving as [[assistant district attorney]]. He was a member of the [[sex crime]]s and [[domestic violence]] units of the DA's office.<ref name="specialist">{{Cite web |date=May 20, 2016 |title=Specialist Prosecutor |url=https://www.scp-ks.org/en/spo/specialist-prosecutor |access-date=November 18, 2022 |website=Kosovo Specialist Chambers & Specialist Prosecutor's Office |language=en |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221118193247/https://www.scp-ks.org/en/spo/specialist-prosecutor |archive-date=November 18, 2022 }}</ref> He joined the [[United States Attorney's Office]] for the [[Eastern District of New York]] in 1999. As an [[assistant U.S. attorney]] at the [[Brooklyn]]-based office, he prosecuted the police officers who brutalized and sexually assaulted [[Abner Louima]], and led the case towards the death penalty—which was later overturned—against [[Ronell Wilson]], who murdered two members of the [[New York Police Department]].<ref name="savage" /><ref name="cnn" /><ref name="WhoIs" />

From 2008 to 2010, Smith worked as investigation coordinator for the [[Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court|Office of the Prosecutor]] of the [[International Criminal Court]] in [[The Hague, Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Jack Smith |url=https://www.justice.gov/usao-mdtn/jack-smith |website=United States Department of Justice |access-date=December 2, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221126014933/https://www.justice.gov/usao-mdtn/jack-smith |archive-date=November 26, 2022 |date=April 14, 2015 |quote=From 2008 to 2010, Jack served as Investigation Coordinator in the Office of the Prosecutor at the International Criminal Court (ICC) in the Hague, Netherlands. |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name="WhoIs">{{cite web |last1=Feuer |first1=Alan |last2=Savage |first2=Charlie |title=Who Is Jack Smith, the New Special Counsel? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/18/us/politics/jack-smith-special-counsel-trump.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=December 8, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221207100244/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/18/us/politics/jack-smith-special-counsel-trump.html |archive-date=December 7, 2022 |date=November 18, 2022 |url-status=live |url-access=limited}}</ref> In that position, he oversaw cases against government officials and militia members accused of war crimes and genocide.<ref name="savage" /><ref name="cnn" /> In 2010, Smith returned to the U.S. to become chief of the [[United States Department of Justice|U.S. Department of Justice]]'s [[Public Integrity Section]] (PIN).<ref name="yost" /><ref name="WhoIs" /> Among his first responsibilities was evaluating current investigations, and he recommended closing investigations into several members of Congress.<ref name="savage" />{{efn|Smith recommended closing investigations into senator [[John Ensign]] and representatives [[Tom DeLay]], [[Jerry Lewis (California politician)|Jerry Lewis]], and [[Alan Mollohan]].<ref name=savage/>}} He spent five years as chief of PIN, where he prosecuted a variety of corruption cases, including those against Virginia governor [[Bob McDonnell]], U.S. representative [[Rick Renzi]], [[Jeffrey Alexander Sterling|Jeffrey Sterling]], a [[Central Intelligence Agency]] agent who shared national secrets,<ref name="politico" /><ref name="WhoIs" /> New York State Assembly speaker [[Sheldon Silver]],<ref name=":3">{{Cite news |last=Hurtado |first=Patricia |date=2022-11-20 |title=New Trump Special Counsel Impartial and Tough, Ex-Colleagues Say |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-11-20/new-trump-special-counsel-impartial-and-tough-ex-colleagues-say |access-date=2024-04-10 |work=Bloomberg |language=en}}</ref> and North Carolina Senator [[John Edwards]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite web |date=2023-07-28 |title=Revisiting Trump special counsel Jack Smith’s failed prosecution of John Edwards |url=https://www.carolinajournal.com/revisiting-trump-special-counsel-jack-smiths-failed-prosecution-of-john-edwards/ |access-date=2024-04-10 |website=Carolina Journal - |language=en-US}}</ref> McDonnell, Renzi, Sterling,<ref name="politico" /> and Silver were found guilty,<ref name=":3" /> though the Supreme Court later unanimously overturned McDonnell's conviction.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Barnes |first=Robert |date=2019-06-27 |title=Supreme Court overturns corruption conviction of former Va. governor McDonnell |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/supreme-court-rules-unanimously-in-favor-of-former-va-robert-f-mcdonnell-in-corruption-case/2016/06/27/38526a94-3c75-11e6-a66f-aa6c1883b6b1_story.html |website=The Washington Post}}</ref> Edwards' case ended in mistrial.<ref name=":4" />

In 2015, Smith became an assistant U.S. attorney in the [[United States District Court for the Middle District of Tennessee|Middle District of Tennessee]], at [[Nashville]].<ref name=npr/><ref name=WhoIs/> He became the acting U.S. attorney in March 2017 upon the resignation of David Rivera, and resigned effective September 2017 after the nomination of [[Donald Q. Cochran]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Stacey |last=Barchenger |url=https://www.tennessean.com/story/news/2017/08/04/jack-smith-resigns-nashville-federal-prosecutors-office/540429001/ |title=Jack Smith to resign from Nashville federal prosecutor's office |newspaper=[[The Tennessean]] |date=August 4, 2017 |accessdate=November 18, 2022}}</ref> Smith became the vice president and head of litigation for [[Hospital Corporation of America]] in 2017.<ref>{{cite press release |url=https://www.scp-ks.org/en/us-prosecutor-jack-smith-appointed-specialist-prosecutor|title=US Prosecutor Jack Smith appointed Specialist Prosecutor|date=May 4, 2018|website=Kosovo Specialist Chambers & Specialist Prosecutor's Office|accessdate=November 21, 2022}}</ref>

On May 7, 2018, Smith was named to a four-year term as chief prosecutor for the [[Kosovo Specialist Chambers]] in The Hague, investigating [[war crimes in the Kosovo War]].<ref name=specialist/><ref name="cnn">{{Cite web |last1=Cohen |first1=Zachary |last2=Scannell |first2=Kara |last3=Herb |first3=Jeremy |last4=Polantz |first4=Katelyn |last5=Duster |first5=Chandelis |date=November 18, 2022 |title=Who is Jack Smith, the special counsel named in the Trump investigations |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/11/18/politics/jack-smith-special-counsel/index.html |access-date=November 19, 2022 |website=[[CNN]] |language=en}}</ref><ref name=npr>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2022/11/18/1137847204/who-is-doj-special-counsel-jack-smith|title=Who is DOJ Special Counsel Jack Smith?|first=Dustin|last=Jones|work=NPR|date=November 18, 2022|accessdate=November 18, 2022}}</ref> During his time as the chief prosecutor, he brought charges against several individuals, including [[Salih Mustafa]]<ref>{{Cite news |last=Berg |first=Stephanie van den |date=September 15, 2021 |title=Ex-rebel denies war crimes as Kosovo tribunal starts first trial |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ex-rebel-denies-war-crimes-kosovo-tribunal-opens-first-trial-2021-09-15/ |access-date=November 19, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |date=13 September 2022 |title=Prosecutors seek 35-year prison term for Kosovo ex-rebel accused of torture |url=https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/prosecutors-seek-35-year-prison-term-kosovo-ex-rebel-accused-torture-2022-09-13/ |work=[[Reuters]] |access-date=16 April 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Perez |first=Evan |date=16 December 2022 |title=Kosovo rebel commander sentenced to 26 years in prison for war crimes in case overseen by the special counsel named in the Trump probe |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/12/16/politics/kosovo-war-crimes-tribunal-jack-smith/index.html |work=[[CNN]] |access-date=16 April 2024}}</ref> and the sitting [[President of Kosovo]], [[Hashim Thaçi]].<ref>{{Cite news |date=November 9, 2020 |title=Kosovo ex-president Thaci denies war crimes in Hague court
 |language=en |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/11/9/kosovo-ex-president-thaci-denies-war-crimes-in-hague-court |access-date=November 28, 2023}}</ref> He took up the post on September 11, 2018, and was appointed to a second term on May 8, 2022, before stepping down on November 18, 2022.<ref name="FormerSpecialists">{{Cite web |date=June 10, 2023 |title=Former Specialist Prosecutors |url=https://www.scp-ks.org/en/spo/former-specialist-prosecutors |access-date=June 10, 2023 |website=Kosovo Specialist Chambers & Specialist Prosecutor's Office |language=en |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230610173819/https://www.scp-ks.org/en/spo/former-specialist-prosecutors |archive-date=June 10, 2023 }}</ref>

== United States special counsel ==
{{Main|Smith special counsel investigation}}

[[File:Classified documents at Mar-a-Lago bathroom.jpg|thumb|Document boxes in a Mar-a-Lago bathroom photographed by the Justice Department]]
On November 18, 2022, United States Attorney General [[Merrick Garland]] appointed Smith [[special counsel]] to oversee the criminal investigations into [[Donald Trump]]'s actions regarding the [[January 6 U.S. Capitol attack]], and Trump's [[FBI investigation into Donald Trump's handling of government documents|handling and storage of government records, including classified documents]] at his [[FBI search of Mar-a-Lago|Mar-a-Lago estate]].<ref name=cnn/><ref name=politico>{{Cite news |first1=Josh |last1=Gerstein |first2=Kyle |last2=Cheney |url=https://www.politico.com/news/2022/11/18/garland-to-appoint-special-counsel-for-trump-criminal-probes-00069451 |title=Garland names Jack Smith special counsel for Trump criminal probes |website=[[Politico]] |date=November 18, 2022 |accessdate=November 18, 2022}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Thrush |first1=Glenn |last2=Savage |first2=Charlie |last3=Haberman |first3=Maggie |last4=Feuer |first4=Alan |title=Garland Names Special Counsel for Trump Inquiries |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221118184932/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/18/us/politics/trump-special-counsel-garland.html |archive-date=November 18, 2022 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/18/us/politics/trump-special-counsel-garland.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=November 19, 2022 |date=November 18, 2022 |url-status=live |url-access=limited}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |url=https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/appointment-special-counsel-0 |title=Appointment of a Special Counsel |work=U.S. Department of Justice |date=November 18, 2022 |access-date=10 June 2023 }}</ref> He worked initially from the [[Netherlands]] while recovering from a fractured leg, injured when he was struck by a scooter while cycling.<ref name=savage/> By early January 2023, Smith had returned to the U.S.<ref>{{Cite news |first1=Perry |last1=Stein |first2=Devlin |last2=Barrett |title=Jack Smith returns to U.S. weeks after becoming Trump special counsel |language=en-US |newspaper=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national-security/2023/01/03/jack-smith-returns-special-counsel-trump/ |date=January 3, 2023|access-date=2023-04-27 |issn=0190-8286 |url-access=limited}}</ref>

On June 8, 2023, [[Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (classified documents case)|a grand jury indicted Trump]] on seven federal criminal charges related to his handling of classified documents. This marked the first time in American history that a serving or former president has been indicted on a federal criminal charge.<ref name="Mangan_Bhattacharjee_6/8/2023">{{cite web | last1=Mangan | first1=Dan |last2=Bhattacharjee |first2=Riya |date=June 8, 2023 |title=Trump indicted on seven criminal counts in classified documents case |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2023/06/08/trump-says-hes-been-indicted-summoned-to-federal-court-in-miami-next-week.html |access-date=June 8, 2023 |work=[[CNBC]]}}</ref> On August 1, Trump was [[Federal prosecution of Donald Trump (election obstruction case)|indicted by a grand jury]] on four more federal felony counts relating to his [[Attempts to overturn the 2020 United States presidential election|attempts to overturn]] the [[2020 United States presidential election|2020 presidential election]] and his conduct during the attack on the Capitol.<ref name=":2" />

== Awards ==
* U.S. Department of Justice Director's Award<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |title=US Prosecutor Tapped to Head Up Kosovo War Crime Court |url=https://www.courthousenews.com/us-prosecutor-appointed-to-investigate-kosovo-war-crimes/ |date=May 7, 2018 |first=Barbara |last=Leonard |access-date=November 18, 2022 |website=[[Courthouse News Service]] |language=en-US}}</ref>
* U.S. Attorney General's Award for Distinguished Service<ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Gans |first=Jared |date=November 18, 2022 |title=Who is Special Counsel Jack Smith? |url=https://thehill.com/homenews/administration/3742261-who-is-special-counsel-jack-smith/ |access-date=November 18, 2022 |website=The Hill |language=en-US}}</ref>
* Federal Bar Association's Younger Federal Attorney Award<ref name=":0" />
* Eastern District Association's Charles Rose Award<ref name=":1" />
* Henry L. Stimson Medal of the New York County Bar Association<ref name=":1" />
* Harvard Law School Wasserstein Fellowship<ref>{{Cite web |title=Past Wasserstein Fellows |url=https://hls.harvard.edu/wasserstein-fellows-program/past-wasserstein-fellows/ |access-date=November 18, 2022 |website=Harvard Law School |language=en-us}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Smith is a competitive [[triathlete]], having taken up swimming when he was in his mid-thirties.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |title=Jack Smith Brings Broad Resume, Low Political Profile to High-Visibility Post |date=November 18, 2022 |first1=Aruna |last1=Viswanatha |first2=Sadie |last2=Gurman |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/jack-smith-brings-broad-resume-low-political-profile-to-high-visibility-post-11668810884 |access-date=November 19, 2022 |url-access=subscription}}</ref><ref name=swimnac>{{Cite interview |title=Masters/Tri Q&A: Jack Smith |url=http://swimnac.com/masterstri-qa-jack-smith/ |access-date=November 20, 2022 |website=Nashville Aquatic Club |date=January 31, 2018 }}</ref> He has completed more than 100 triathlons and at least nine [[Ironman competition]]s around the world.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-06-09 |title=Who is Jack Smith? What to know about the special counsel who charged Trump. |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/06/09/jack-smith-special-counsel-trump/ |access-date=2023-08-02 |newspaper=Washington Post |language=en}}</ref> In July 2011, he married [[Katy Chevigny]],<ref>{{Cite magazine |year=2012 |title=Class Notes |magazine=[[Harvard Law Bulletin]] |volume=63 |page=58 |url=https://docplayer.net/94980938-Harvard-law-new-connections-between-theory-and-practice-bulletin-l-real-world-perspectives-and-hands-on-training-v.html |access-date=10 June 2023 |quote=On July 23, Jack Smith and Katy Chevigny were married on the banks of the St. Lawrence River in upstate New York by the Honorable Nicholas G. Garaufis. Smith is serving as the chief of the public integrity section of the U.S. Department of Justice in Washington, D.C., where the couple lives.}}</ref> a documentary filmmaker<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/09/30/style/weddings-katy-chevigny-jonathan-chen.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|title=WEDDINGS; Katy Chevigny, Jonathan Chen|language=en-US|url-status=live|date=September 30, 2001|access-date=June 17, 2023|archive-date=November 19, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221119183126/https:/www.nytimes.com/2001/09/30/style/weddings-katy-chevigny-jonathan-chen.html|url-access=limited}}</ref> known for ''[[Becoming (2020 documentary film)|Becoming]]'', a 2020 documentary about [[Michelle Obama]]. They have a daughter.<ref name=swimnac/> The couple lived in the Netherlands starting in 2018,<ref name="Liverpool football"/> before moving to [[Washington, D.C.]] in December 2022, shortly after Smith was appointed as special counsel.<ref name=NYTimes2023-06-08/>
